bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas and Lydia Cabrera, September 29, 1953

div1.p: Hench appreciates Cabrera and Rojas nominating him for the Grand Cross of Finlay and the decoration of Carlos Manuel de Cespedes

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas and Lydia Cabrera, September 29, 1953
div1.opener:
September 29, 1953
Senorita Maria Teresa Rojas
Senorita Lidia Cabrera
Quinta San Jose
Redencion
Marianao
Habana, Cuba
My dear Tina and Lidia:
div1.p:
Mary, her mother, our daughter Mary and her husband, Jack, and I have just
returned from Europe. I hope you got the card which I believe we sent from
Innsbruck. We thought of you often as we stayed at the Meurice in Paris
going and coming. Indeed Mary was “sure” that we would run into you, so
much so that she inquired at the Hotel Meurice, hoping that you might be ar-
riving some time during our European stay. I spoke in Geneva and then we
hired a car for a month's trip around Switzerland and into Austria and
southern Germany.

What wonderful friends you are to take so much of an interest in me and to
nominate me for the two splendid honors which you mention. I realize that
the matters have probably gone no further than nominations and that nothing
may come of these nominations, even though you, with your faith and friend-
ship, hope that the nominations will be approved. It would of course be a
great honor to receive the Grand Cross of Finlay and the decoration of Carlos
Manuel de Cespedes but if I were one of those asked to approve the nominations
I fear that I would wonder why the higher honor should be given to me so soon
after the other one. I suspect that someone might say, “Didn't the other
honor satisfy him? Why shouldn't he wait a while before being promoted to a
higher grade?”

Nevertheless, it is indeed pleasant to think that something might come of
the nominations, but most of all it has given me wonderful pleasure and a
very happy feeling in the heart to know that you two very good friends want
to do such a very gracious thing. If the miracle should happen and one or
both of these honors materialize, I can assure you that Mary and I would do
our very best to fly down for the ceremony. Even though the visit would have
to be short, the great pleasure of seeing you would be well worth the trip.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
